subject: Re: [junit] Looking for a sample java project for using JUnit
msgSnippet: ... Absolutely but sometimes it really helps to have a good example to get you started and explain the best style. For instance in eclipse they have a fairly
messageBody:
On 1/18/06, David Saff <saff@...> wrote:
>
>
> Cool! I've found that the best way to learn is to write something
> myself. I think of something that I've been interested in doing lately,
> and write some code in that direction, such as a digital jukebox, a
> custom news aggregator, or a screensaver. I'm not intending to finish
> the job, but it helps me write code that I understand, since JUnit is
> the thing I'm trying to learn. If I try to learn using someone else's
> code, then I'm never sure if problems are coming from JUnit or the other
> code.
>
> Not only that, but once you have a little experience with JUnit, google
> for "test-driven development". That's fun stuff. Good luck,


Absolutely but sometimes it really helps to have a good example to get you
started and explain the best style. For instance in eclipse they have a
fairly sophisticated test runner that goes and finds all the tests in
plugin/package/class and runs them so you don't need hard to maintain
suites.

That said I don't know what project to recommend Sreedhar that will do a
good job of illustrating current JUnit best practices in Eclipse. Where's JB
when you need him :-)?

Mark
----------------------------------------------------------------------
